title: Boston police now required to wear nametags under new contract extension
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston police patrol officers now required to wear nametags under new contract with the city.
The contract extension also includes wage increases and free gym access, costing $6.7 million for one year.
Mayor Wu emphasizes transparency and trust, contrasting BPD policies with federal immigration enforcement tactics.

title: The backlash has arrived: 6 takeaways from a good night for Democrats
author: Reid J. Epstein, The New York Times
bullets: Democrats secured significant victories, including governorships in Virginia and New Jersey, despite not having President Trump on the ballot.
Zohran Mamdani won the New York City mayoral race, offering a blueprint for Democratic politics with his progressive platform.
Voter turnout favored Democrats in nonpresidential elections since 2017, impacting races in states like California and Virginia.

title: The Swedish candy craze has taken Boston by storm. Here’s where you can get it.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Bostonians are buying Swedish candy at citywide pick-and-mix stores after a viral TikTok fueled demand.
Madeleine's Candy Shop, The Sweetish Fish, and lil sweet treat are key stores offering Swedish candy in Boston.
Swedish candy is popular for its unique flavors and healthier ingredients, sparking a new trend among Americans.

title: Few answers as Woburn-based Newpro files for bankruptcy after sudden shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Newpro, a Woburn-based home improvement company, abruptly closed on Oct. 28 and filed for bankruptcy.
Employees and customers were impacted by Newpro's closure with no prior WARN notice or explanation provided.
Renovo Home Partners, Newpro's parent company, and its subsidiaries have joined the bankruptcy filing in Delaware.

title: Snag 20% off JetBlue flights in December during this limited-time sale
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: JetBlue offers a 20% discount on flights for travel between Dec. 2-18, excluding Fridays and Sundays.
The two-day sale ends Nov. 6, 11:59 p.m. ET; bookings must be made on jetblue.com using promo code TAKE20.
Up to 40% off is available on round-trip flights with JetBlue Vacations packages for travel through March 31, 2026.

title: WWII veteran’s remains are being returned to Weymouth
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Private Alfred Thomas Langevin's remains, missing since World War II, are being returned to Weymouth after 81 years.
Langevin was reported missing in November 1944 during combat in Germany's Hürtgen Forest, with identification confirmed in 2025.
A public viewing and funeral procession will occur in Weymouth, concluding with a burial at Fairmount Cemetery.

title: Embattled Everett mayor loses reelection bid to city councilor
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: City Councilor Robert Van Campen defeated longtime Everett Mayor Carlo DeMaria by over 600 votes, ending DeMaria's 18-year tenure.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria faced controversies, including $180,000 in questionable longevity payments, which led to protests and dissatisfaction.
Van Campen emphasized accountability and transparency, focusing on school overcrowding and traffic issues during his campaign for mayor.

title: ‘The sun is up and we’re fighting’: Bill O’Brien’s fiery response to question about Boston College football
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Boston College football coach Bill O'Brien reacted strongly to a question about the team's 1-8 record at a press conference.
O'Brien emphasized his team's competitiveness and positivity, despite the challenging second year of his coaching tenure at BC.
The Eagles, with three games left, face uncertainty about O'Brien's future, though they have a top 35 recruiting class for 2026.

title: Apparently, Mass. had a ‘gustnado’ touch down Monday night — and more wind is coming
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A 'gustnado' struck Massachusetts on Monday, with wind gusts reaching 40 mph in Worcester, according to the National Weather Service.
Southern New England is under a high wind watch, with gusts predicted to reach 55-65 mph from Wednesday night to Thursday morning.
Wind speeds on Cape Cod near Provincetown could reach 70-75 mph, potentially causing tree damage and power outages.

title: Trio sought in alleged unprovoked Halloween attack at downtown T station
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: MBTA police seek help identifying three suspects in an alleged unprovoked Halloween attack at State Street station.
The incident occurred around 11 p.m. on October 31; surveillance photos were released by MBTA Transit Police.
Anyone with information can contact MBTA police at 617-222-1050, with the option to remain anonymous.
